All the latest Manchester United news and transfer gossip, including updates on Jadon Sancho, Matthijs de Ligt, Jarrad Brathwaite and Leny Yoro
The transfer window could be about to spark into life and Manchester United fans will be hoping for more news on incomings over the next few days.

Joshua Zirkzee became United's first signing of the summer over the weekend with the striker joining from Serie A side Bologna. The Dutchman will join up with his new teammates soon with pre-season now underway.

United kicked off the friendlies with a 1-0 defeat against Rosenborg on Monday night, and they are back in action on Saturday when they take on Rangers. There is a possibility that more signings could be closer by the time that match comes around.
One of those is defender Leny Yoro. United have had a bid accepted and the player has agreed to sign for the club..
Work will be continuing behind the scenes to add to the squad between now and next month's deadline day.
Find out the latest and keep up to date with the latest United news in our live blog below.
According to a report by The Times, Crystal Palace have 'increased their valuation' of centre-back Marc Guehi to north of £70million.
The defender, who enjoyed a successful Euro 2024 campaign with England, playing a key role in their run to the final, has been linked with a move to United at various stages in recent weeks.
Despite closing in on the addition of Lille's Leny Yoro, the addition of at least one more central defender has not been ruled out.
It is claimed that Palace, prior to the European Championship, valued Guehi at around £50m, but have now increased their value of the player to 'over £70m'.

Mason Greenwood is now in Marseille after flying to France last night. One of the reasons why Roberto de Zerbi may be so staunchly defensive of that deal is De Zerbi's agency is believed to be finalising it.

De Zerbi has already promised to defend Greenwood as if he was his own child amid rancour in Marseille over his imminent arrival. De Zerbi, of course, was among the managers that United considered to replace Erik ten Hag in the summer.
De Zerbi was combustible behind the scenes at Brighton and, given his ardent support of Greenwood, it is just as well United did not take a punt on him.
According to a report by Portuguese newspaper Record, as cited by The Peoples Person, a deal to take Joao Neves from Benfica to Paris Saint-Germain is 'drawing close'.
The midfielder has been heavily linked with a move to United for months amid the club's plan to strengthen their midfield options this summer.

United, in June, reportedly saw a bid just north of £50million bid knocked back for the Portuguese international. It has been regularly reported that Benfica have been holding out for the value of his €120million release clause.
However, it is now reported that PSG could be set to land the 19-year-old for €70m. The report adds that Neves has said he wants to move to the French capital.
Former Lille boss Jocelyn Gourvennec, who worked with Leny Yoro at the French club, has compared him with Barcelona ace Joules Kounde.
Yoro is closing in on a move to Old Trafford after undergoing a medical yesterday (Wednesday). He is expected to join the Reds in a deal worth €70million (£58.7m).
Gourvennec, speaking to Sky Sports, said:

"When I knew him in his beginning when he was 16, he was a very complete player, but a little bit tender. As a young defender, it is normal. He has a good reading of the game, he is very good technically, can play short and long passes, is good in duels and he is more ready now than in the beginning. He is fast, has height, is in good in duels, both in the air and on the ground, he is good technically and is intelligent. He is always calm. He is a little bit like Jules Kounde. I had Jules Kounde at Bordeaux and I put him in the starting XI. He was the same; intelligent and very calm."
Fulham are continuing to hold 'internal discussions' about whether or not to submit a fresh offer for United midfielder Scott McTominay according to a report by Sky Sports.
The Scotland international, who netted 10 goals for United last term, is considered as one of the most sellable assets within the squad that could be sold to generate funds this summer.
It has been reported that Fulham have already seen a £17million bid for McTominay rejected and they are now mulling over whether to launch a second offer.
According to a report by Sky Sports, United are in 'dialogue' with Paris Saint-Germain to sign midfielder Manuel Ugarte.
The Uruguay international has been heavily linked with a move to M16 over the last few weeks amid United's plans to strengthen their midfield options.
They want to strengthen the base of their engine room with a new defensive-midfielder after Casemiro's decline last season.
Experienced midfielder Adrien Rabiot will 'hold talks' with United about the prospect of a move to Old Trafford on a free transfer, according to a report by Football Italia.
The France international is currently a free agent after leaving Italian side Juventus. The defensive-midfielder spent five years in Italy but is now looking for an alternative challenge.
United wanted to sign Rabiot two years ago but the move broke down due to the midfielder's wage demands.
It is reported that a host of clubs are now looking to sign him, including United and arch rivals Liverpool. It is reported that he will 'discuss' his future with both clubs.
Video footage of Mason Greenwood arriving in Marseille has emerged ahead of his proposed move to the French club.
Greenwood's time as a United player is now nearing an end, with his next move soon expected to be announced.
Greenwood est olympien pic.twitter.com/zsrXI5cxRx
In case you somehow missed it yesterday, United are closing in on the signing of Lille defender Leny Yoro.
United had a €62m (£52m) offer accepted by Lille last week and the 18-year-old has decided to join the club, despite interest from Real Madrid.
For the full story on the Red Devis' deal for the French centre-back, click here.
Hello and welcome back to our United live blog.
Stick with us throughout the day for the latest news on Leny Yoro, Mason Greenwood and more!
That's all from us tonight. Thanks for following.
Mason Greenwood understood to be travelling to Marseille this evening to complete his permanent move from #mufc.
Manchester United suffered a defeat in their first pre-season game of 2024 as they were beaten 1-0 by Rosenberg on Tuesday.
However, Erik ten Hag's side are back in action on Saturday when they face Scottish Premiership giants Rangers at Murrayfield.
Paris Saint-Germain are reportedly trying to speed up negotiations to sign Joao Neves in an attempt to fend off competition for the 19-year-old.
Neves has been linked with a whole host of Europe's top clubs in recent weeks - including Manchester United and Liverpool.
But according to French publication L'Équipe, the Ligue 1 champions are "positive about a quick outcome" in their efforts to sign the Portugal international.
Tottenham Hotspur manager Ange Postecoglou is reportedly one of the FA's potential candidates to succeed Gareth Southgate as England manager.
On Tuesday, Southgate announced that he would be stepping down from his position after nearly eight years in charge of the Three Lions, who on Sunday were defeated in the Euro 2024 final.
The Telegraph claim that Postecoglou, who was appointed as Spurs boss last summer, has "been tracked" by the FA for years.

Manchester United have the 'flexibility' with their current profit and sustainability rules (PSR) situation to move for Lille defender Leny Yoro but they will need to sell off talent if they are to make future additions, such as Jarrad Branthwaite.
That is the view of Reach Football's Business of Football expert Dave Powell, who has outlined United's current financial situation after a busy start to their summer transfer window.
United have sold three players already, with Donny van de Beek (Girona), Willy Kambwala (Villarreal) and Alvaro Fernandez (Benfica) moved on.

In terms of incomings, they have already announced the £36million signing of Dutch international forward Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna and they are set to seal the arrival of teenage defender Leny Yoro from Lille imminently.
The 18-year-old will join for an initial £42m, with the rest of the fee made up of add-ons as United look to overhaul their defensive options.

They have also agreed personal terms with Bayern Munich's Matthijs De Ligt and have had two bids rejected for Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite. However, they may need to sell the likes of Mason Greenwood and Victor Lindelof to help fund those deals.
Read the full story, here.

Mason Greenwood has edged closer to leaving Manchester United this summer. The 22-year-old forward spent last season on loan at Getafe in the Spanish top flight, scoring eight goals and providing six assists in 33 games.
With his contract at Old Trafford expiring next year, the Red Devils look set to cash in...

According to Fabrizio Romano, Jean-Clair Todibo has informed Nice that he wants to join Juventus. The 24-year-old defender was briefly linked with a move to Man United earlier this summer before it was revealed that a couldn't be completed due to UEFA's ownership rules.

The report states that, while West Ham have had a bid accepted by the French club, Todibo's currently waiting for an offer from the Old Lady. Romano adds that the Hammers are aware of the centre-back's stance...

According to talkSPORT, West Ham are in advanced talks with Man United over a move for Aaron Wan-Bissaka. The 26-year-old defender currently faces an uncertain future at Old Trafford, with his contract set to expire in June 2025.

The report states that the Red Devils are willing to sell Wan-Bissaka this summer and they're looking to recuperate at least £15m. Man United signed the right-back from Crystal Palace for £50m in 2019...

According to the Daily Mail, Man United are 'highly unlikely' to pursue Gareth Southgate if they decide to sack Erik ten Hag in the near future. The 53-year-old was heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford before Erik ten Hag penned an extension earlier this month.

On Tuesday, Southgate announced he would resign as England head coach after a 2-1 defeat to Spain in the Euro 2024 final. The report states that the former Three Lions boss remains well-liked by INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

Speaking to talkSPORT BET, Ally McCoist backed Scott McTominay to become a key player for Erik ten Hag at Man United this season. He said: "Scott McTominay will stay at Manchester United under Erik ten Hag.
"You can count on one hand the number of players who have been successful under Ten Hag at Manchester United – McTominay is probably top of the list.
"He’s come in and handled the responsibility of playing for United far better than some of the other players so I think he’ll have a good future at the club under Ten Hag."

Speaking on CBS Sports in May, Alessandro Del Piero offered Jadon Sancho some advice. He said: "If a player like him can play these kind of games, with this kind of quality, you need to go to Man United."

The Juventus legend added: "With Man United they are supposed to go [to the Champions League] every year. I know they are struggling, but you have to, you want to achieve with the big clubs and this is the destiny of Man United and the destiny of him at some point.
"I hope for him that he can go there and perform in that way, with that personality, I really hope so. Tonight he was unbelievable, he was dribbling everybody."

Speaking to German TV channel Sport1, Lothar Matthaus addressed the futures of Matthijs de Ligt and Joshua Kimmich at Bayern Munich. He said: "For me, Matthijs de Ligt is someone who has the Bayern Munich gene.
"Joshua Kimmich is also someone for whom I don’t really need a new number six. But these are decisions made by the club and the player. Everyone thinks a little differently."

Angel Gomes has previously backed Leny Yoro to be a huge success at Man United if he does decide to make the move. Speaking to Eurosport, as quoted by the Mirror, the former Red Devils midfielder said: "As soon as he arrived in the group, I understood that he was going to reach the summits.
"When I discovered the pros at the age of 16 at Manchester United, I understood that it was different. He already had the right temperament.
"That’s not normal for a 16- or 17-year-old player arriving. It’s like he’s already an experienced player and it showed in the way he trained, the way he behaved. His progress was obvious."

According to Fabrizio Romano in a column for CaughtOffside, Harry Maguire remains content at Man United despite question marks over his future. The Red Devils continue to be heavily linked with some high-profile defenders, like Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro,as Erik ten Hag looks to bolster his backline.

The report states that Maguire could leave Old Trafford if he chooses to, however, there are currently no 'concrete' talks or negotiations regarding a potential exit this summer. The 31-year-old centre-half sees his contract expire in June 2025.

In an interview with the the MailOnline, Eric Cantona said: "No, never. I think the stadium is very important. I remember the first day I came to Manchester United, I could feel the ghosts of the club, of the players, and everything. The energy of the club.

"The history. It’s a heritage. You can feel the soul of the club, you can feel the energy of the past strongly. It’s very important. I cannot imagine Manchester United without Old Trafford. I cannot imagine Liverpool without Anfield or Real Madrid without the Santiago Bernabeu.
"I think some clubs change their stadiums and lose their soul, like Arsenal for example. When they left Highbury, they lost the soul of this club."

The Manchester Evening News understands that Leny Yoro has agreed to join United in a deal rising to €70m (£58.7m). It's believed that the Red Devils had a €62m (£52m) offer accepted by Lille last week and the 18-year-old defender has decided to join the club, despite interest from Real Madrid.

United are open to signing up to three centre backs as part of a drastic overhaul of their defence. The club have verbally agreed personal terms with Matthijs de Ligt and had two bids rejected by Everton for Jarrad Branthwaite.
Yoro will likely be available to travel with the club to Los Angeles for their pre-season tour next week.

According to The Athletic, Leny Yoro will soon fly to the United Kingdom for a medical and to finalise personal terms before a potential transfer to United. The report states that the 18-year-old defender initially favoured a move to Real Madrid, but Lille have accepted a €62m (£52m) bid from the Red Devils.

The Athletic states that Erik ten Hag's side pushing to wrap up a deal for the teenager's signature, but there's till work to be done. Yoro featured 32 times in Ligue 1 last season, guiding Lille to Europa League qualification.

He, who sees his contract at Stade Pierre-Mauroy expire in 2025, also played a crucial role for the French outfit in the Conference League, helping them reach the quarter-finals. After such an impressive campaign, Yoro courted interest from top European clubs.
Jonathan Tah continues to be linked with a move to Man United this summer. The Bayer Leverkusen defender was widely expected to join Bayern Munich, but now a fresh update has emerged.

headline: De Ligt signs, £40m Ugarte deal, Branthwaite call - Man United's next transfer after Leny Yoro
body: Leny Yoro is closing in on becoming Manchester United's second summer signing after Joshua Zirkzee completed his move earlier this week, but who should be next?
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United have agreed a deal to sign Leny Yoro from Lille. United had an offer accepted last week and the 18-year-old has decided to join the club, despite interest from Real Madrid.

The fee is expected to rise to around €70million (£58.7m) for the Frenchman, who was named in the Ligue 1 Team of the Year after impressing last season. Yoro is poised to become United's second signing of the summer after Joshua Zirkzee arrived from Bologna in a £36.5m move.

It's expected to take their spending to £95.2m for the summer, with more incomings anticipated as they look to sell several squad members. Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Casemiro, Mason Mount and Harry Maguire are among the players being linked with moves away as United look to raise some cash.
But who else should United sign this summer? MEN writers have their say on who the Red Devils should target as their next and third arrival in the transfer window...

A centre-back and a striker were the priority for United at the start of this window and if they secure both before heading off on tour it will have to be considered an excellent start. The reality is sales are now required to boost the budget and who goes might condition who is next to arrive.
United will have to sell another central defender, probably Victor Lindelof, and there are midfielders who could depart, notably Casemiro, while there have been bids for Scott McTominay.

Another, slightly more senior centre-back, would be a preference and Matthijs de Ligt could yet tick that box. The most interesting situation is Casemiro's, however. If United are to replace him it probably needs to happen sooner rather than later and that is why midfield should be the next area to look at.

Before the transfer window opened, I said United's priority must be signing a quality defensive midfielder to replace Casemiro and my opinion hasn't changed. The Brazilian's regression was significant last season and persisting with him in the new campaign is inadvisable.
Finding the right player to succeed Casemiro is the challenge. Joao Palhinha appealed, but he's joined Bayern Munich from Fulham and the market isn't bursting with options.
Nonetheless, now a forward and a defender have been brought in - although Leny Yoro's move isn't official yet - United should focus their efforts on signing that player.
Perhaps PSG's midfielder Ugrarte fits the billing and he'd add to the South American influence in the dressing room.

It's clear as day that United need to strengthen their midfield this summer. They need someone to partner Kobbie Mainoo for the long-term as I am not convinced Casemiro can still cut it at the top level. The Brazilian looked way off his best last season, and at 32, should United look to the future? I think so.

Crystal Palace starlet Adam Wharton is the man they should look at. He has impressed since moving to Palace from Blackburn in January and could immediately solve United's midfield problem. That is the area United should look at next, with Wharton the most ideal candidate available right now.

Signing Yoro is a huge coup for United: it also means they don't need to get sucked into time-sensitive transfer sagas, overbidding for targets as they have done in previous summers. So, what do they need to do next? United could do with another centre-back along with Yoro: Matthijs De Ligt fits the bill at the right price. Jarrad Branthwaite would be a superb signing, but looks too expensive at this point - especially with Everton left baffled by the Yoro fee.

A left-back would be welcome given Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia's injury records, while Ten Hag also desperately needs a defensive midfielder: PSG's Manuel Ugarte looks a good prospect for an affordable fee, but that deal likely rests on Casemiro being sold. In truth, the rest of United's transfer window hinges on who can be sold to raise more funds.

If Ineos can get Casemiro, Mason Greenwood, Christian Eriksen and one of Victor Lindelof or Harry Maguire (or both of them) out the door, then De Ligt, Ugarte and a left-back would represent upgrades across the squad. Marcus Rashford and Jadon Sancho leaving now looks less likely, but if United could sell either then I would also pick up a winger and/or a striker: Ivan Toney and Federico Chiesa would offer goals, experience and depth at affordable prices.

Capturing Matthijs de Ligt as well as Yoro is a mouth-watering prospect but one that could be scuppered by past transfer failings. United are thought to be operating on a net transfer budget of just £50m, having so far received an initial £10m for two sales and spent £36m on the arrival of Joshua Zirkzee.

The purchase of Yoro will take the net spend up to £85m with a midfielder still to buy. The probable exit of Mason Greenwood for around £27m will lower this back down to circa £58m but sales will still be needed.
De Ligt would be a great addition but will cost £42m, money that ought to be first spent on a midfielder. United are expected to offload Casemiro and a replacement will be needed.

£101m-rated Joao Neves is too expensive for a player with just 75 club appearances, while a return deal for Sofyan Amrabat seems risky, albeit much cheaper. If a deal under £40m can be secured for Manuel Ugarte, it might be worth the punt.
It's been a promising transfer window for United so far this summer and it will be a welcome relief to fans that they haven't been dragged into the drawn-out transfer sagas of previous years.

If and when Yoro joins then Ten Hag will have two of Europe's brightest young stars joining after the arrival of Zirkzee. It's a mouthwatering prospect to go alongside other young talent including Mainoo, Garnacho and Hojlund.

But midfield remains a concern as United cannot afford to go a whole season with Casemiro trying to cover spaces which left United's defence exposed on countless occasions last term. The priority now has to be a defensive midfielder with PSG's Manuel Ugarte looking like a player who could fit into their new philosophy under Dan Ashworth and Ineos.
Joao Neves would also be a great signing but the fee required to complete a deal is likely to be beyond United's financial means in this window.

The signings of Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro add to both the front and back line options for Erik ten Hag in the upcoming season, so concentration should be now on completing the spine with a midfield addition.

The uncertainty over the future of Casemiro means that United will be short in the area if he is sold. The team will need a long-term partner for Kobbie Mainoo at the base of midfield, Sofyan Amrabat played the role in the FA Cup final but has since turned to Fiorentina.
Manuel Ugarte has been linked with a move to Old Trafford and could be the solution. At just 23-years old he is still young, meaning that the position could be sorted for years to come.
He is said to be available for around £38 million which could prove to be a shrewd long-term investment in midfield.

headline: Leny Yoro transfer hints at Manchester United's new market strategy
body: Leny Yoro caught the eye of those in the Old Trafford directors' box as a 16-year-old and he has the support network to succeed at Man United.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Leny Yoro's first and last appearances for Lille were against Nice. His debut, as a 16-year-old, came in the presence of Sir Dave Brailsford.

Brailsford was at the Allianz Riviera Stadium in his role as the Ineos sporting director of Ineos-owned Nice. He was flanked by Josh Thompson, the group's sports project manager already dubbed Brailsford's "bag man" by some at Manchester United.

Where Brailsford goes, Thompson usually follows. He wandered through the mixed zone with Brailsford and Sir Jim Ratcliffe after the FA Cup final and appeared to advise Ratcliffe on an exit strategy that avoided the press.

Thompson closely assists Brailsford and fellow United football board member Jean-Claude Blanc to drive the performance levels. Yoro has gone up a few levels since Brailsford first clapped eyes on him.
The teenager came on in the 78th minute with Lille 2-1 up in May 2022 and they clinched a 3-1 victory. Three of Yoro's 68 appearances for Lille came against Nice.

United sporting director Dan Ashworth championed the development of a signing from Lille at Brighton six years ago. He joined two months before Ashworth's appointment but it was under the Ashworth-Graham Potter axis he emerged into one of the Premier League's most dominant midfielders. Yves Bissouma restored Tottenham's backbone last season.

Ratcliffe said earlier this year United would opt for a grassroots approach in the transfer market and Yoro is very green. Ratcliffe last month lamented the disadvantages of multi-club ownership in the transfer market as the Nice centre back Jean-Clair Todibo had been eyed by United but is now headed for West Ham.

Yoro, six years the 24-year-old Todibo's junior and without any international recognition, is a long-term addition at a club in need of significant short-term gains. Yoro's final fee could trump Lisandro Martinez's yet United lack longevity at centre half, where three of the defenders are in their 30s.

Last season was, in all probability, Victor Lindelof's last with United and next season could be the curtain call for Harry Maguire and Jonny Evans. Yoro will be afforded a season of adaptation, as unforgiving as his position is.

Eight league games in an untried Europa League format should help him find his feet. Maguire and Evans are sound professionals who have been around the block and will offer expert guidance. It is a pity for Yoro that Raphael Varane, another teenage centre half at a northern French club United coveted 13 years ago, came to the end of the road at the club.

Following Zinedine Zidane's intervention in 2011, Sir Alex Ferguson turned to Phil Jones, also 19. Jones is proof a raw defender can make a fearless start at United, even eliciting a barely credulous comparison with Duncan Edwards from Sir Bobby Charlton.

It helped that Jones was a homebird from Blackburn and accustomed to the Premier League. He was emboldened by United's gung-ho approach to the 2011-12 season as they plundered 21 goals in their first six games, which placed him mostly out of harm's way.

Yoro's age will not protect him from scrutiny but he need only look to his left at Martinez, written off by Jamie Carragher (and others) after two appearances. Despite an injury-plagued year, Martinez has been the most successful signing of the Erik ten Hag era.

Newly-signed centre backs at United used to endure baptisms of fire until Eric Bailly, usually the fire starter rather than firefighter, eased some of the heat. He was the man of the match in his first two appearances in 2016, Maguire had a steady start three years later and ditto Varane in 2021. Lindelof was unsteady in his first season and Martinez's mare lasted two games before he helped neutralise a daunting Liverpool attack at Old Trafford.

Bailly was 22 when he was unveiled, Lindelof 23, Maguire 26 and Varane 28. Lindelof was culpable for both goals in newly-promoted Huddersfield's win over United in October 2017 and left the John Smith's Stadium with two hoodies pulled up, skulking out like a criminal leaving court.

Yoro's compatriot, Patrice Evra, was 24 when his debut at Manchester City lasted 45 minutes with United 2-0 down, an experience he likened to being put in a washing machine. Sixteen and a half years later, Tyrell Malacia was hooked at the interval at the same venue with City 4-0 up.

These tales should inspire rather than instil dread in Yoro. He has a good support network among the other centre halves and will be flanked by the bullish Diogo Dalot and backed by the popular Andre Onana.
As well as those who spotted him on the French Riviera.

headline: Leny Yoro deal shows Sir Jim Ratcliffe has kept his promise on Manchester United transfers
body: Man Utd are set to sign an 18-year-old centre-back who was wanted by Real Madrid and the deal is a major milestone for Ineos.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Sir Jim Ratcliffe didn't shy away from the biggest issue that has held Manchester United back when he completed his £1.25bn deal to invest in the club in February.

"I think recruitment in the modern game is critical. Manchester United have clearly spent a lot of money but they haven't done as well as some other clubs," Ratcliffe said in his first sit-down interview as the club's minority owner.
"So when I was talking about being best-in-class in all aspects of football, recruitment is probably top of the list."

The 71-year-old has never really hid his feelings about the transfer operation at Old Trafford. A few years ago he called United the "dumb money" in football and a look at the rewards for the £1.6bn spend since 2013 would make that a fair assessment.

In recent months he has touched again on recruitment. He told the Geraint Thomas Cycling Club podcast that "the solution isn’t spending a lot of money on a couple of great players", and then said he wanted to sign the next Kylian Mbappe rather than the man himself.

The extent to which Ratcliffe has placed recruitment at the top of the list in areas to improve can be seen in the overhaul of roles at Old Trafford. Since February, Ineos have appointed Dan Ashworth as sporting director, Jason Wilcox as technical director and Christopher Vivell as interim director of recruitment. Three executives with vast experience in transfers and a reputation as shrewd operators.

They are making a good start as well. The deal for Joshua Zirkzee was wrapped up quickly after his involvement in Euro 2024 came to an end, with a deal agreed with Bologna that helped United navigate their own financial concerns. But it is the second transfer of the summer that looks set to cause a storm.

When United had a bid accepted by Lille for 18-year-old Leny Yoro recently there still wasn't a feeling it was going to happen. The teenager is out of contract next summer so held the ace cards and it had long been expected that he wanted to move to Real Madrid.

But United's aggressive approach in making an offer Lille clearly couldn't refuse tilted the balance and they have convinced him his future can be at Old Trafford. At an initial £52m it is a large fee, rising to £58.7m with add-ons, but that remains well below what Everton want for Jarrad Branthwaite. Yoro has far more high-level exposure at this stage of his career than Branthwaite had at 18, when he spent time on loan at Blackburn and played 10 games in the Championship.

Yoro has already racked up 46 appearances in Ligue 1 and is probably the most highly-rated young centre-back in Europe. The fact he made the Ligue 1 team of the year speaks of his talent and he doesn't turn 19 until November. He could be a United centre-back for years to come.

The deal would certainly be a feather in the cap for Ineos and particularly for Ashworth, Wilcox and Vivell. Convincing Yoro to put aside his ambitions to play for Real Madrid is a significant achievement and he has clearly been sold on the idea of progressing his career at Old Trafford.

They have also acted decisively. Yoro's move to Real had looked like a formality, but while the European champions waited to play hardball over a fee, United stepped in. It is an example of the quick-thinking and nimbleness that Ratcliffe would want the club to show.
There is more work to be in this window, but in a significant couple of months for Ineos they are laying down a marker already.

headline: Manchester United might copy Pep Guardiola tactic and spring Leny Yoro surprise
body: Leny Yoro is closing in on a move to Man United and could be used in a different defensive role to his natural position.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United fans will admit Pep Guardiola has been at the forefront of evolving tactics.

Guardiola made playing false nines fashionable, he introduced playing out from the back to England and, more recently, began to play central defenders in full-back roles. Other managers have followed Guardiola's tactical innovations and his former assistant manager Mikel Arteta picked up the central defender idea and ran with it at the Emirates.

Arteta has played Ben White out of position and Guardiola has changed the roles of Nathan Ake and Josko Gvardiol, with all three of those regularly playing as full-backs last season, providing extra defensive solidity on the wings and an advantage in build-up play.

Centre backs tend to be significantly better one-on-one defenders than traditional full-backs and that's an obvious positive, but playing a natural centre half as a full-back also allows teams to have a back-three in build-up, which helps to press high and defend counter-attacks.

Playing central defenders out of position became a popular trend last season and Liverpool and Aston Villa played Joe Gomez and Ezri Konsa as their full-backs respectively. The four teams who finished at the top Premier League all used the innovation, which suggests there's an advantage in doing so if implemented correctly.

Now enter United and Erik ten Hag, who has often instructed his full-backs to play an inverted role, which is why Diogo Dalot comes into midfield from the right. Perhaps Ten Hag is happy with his current system and believes it doesn't need to be tweaked, but an elite manager adapts to the players at his disposal and the United squad is changing this summer, with Leny Yoro coming in and Aaron Wan-Bissaka expected to leave.

Wan-Bissaka has entered the final year of his contract and selling him this summer is the last opportunity to recoup a decent fee for someone who was signed for £50m in the summer of 2019, with West Ham said to be interested.

Although moving on Wan-Bissaka would leave Dalot as the only senior right-back in the squad, Yoro is flying to Manchester for a medical and is an option in that role. Yoro is a natural centre-back and made 44 appearances at the heart of Lille's defence last season, but starting in central defence at just 18 years old in the Premier League is bound to be a tough challenge and he could be eased into the team at right-back.

Like every player at his age, Yoro needs time to physically develop and playing him at right-back would allow him to improve and gain experience without coming under the cosh in central defence. As the last line of defence, centre-backs are exposed and tested by the opposition more than any other outfield players and Yoro might not be ready for that challenge.

He is a defender for the future - United hope he'll become one of the world's best - but immediately chucking him into the deep end is inadvisable. Yoro has the qualities to excel at right-back for United.

It might not be a position Yoro has played before, but he's comfortable with the ball at his feet, he intelligently reads the game and his natural athleticism will help him adapt. His long-term future is in the middle but it wouldn't be a surprise to see him at right-back this season.

headline: Manchester United 'take Ivan Toney transfer stance' amid Manuel Ugarte deal change
body: Latest Manchester United transfer news and gossip with updates on Brentford star Ivan Toney and Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United continue to be linked with several potential transfer targets this summer.

The Reds have already confirmed their first signing with Joshua Zirkzee arriving from Bologna. The striker has signed a long-term contract with United that will see him remain at Old Trafford until 2029, while Leny Yoro is set to join him.

Erik ten Hag has been busy assessing his squad in the early weeks of pre-season training. However, some members of the squad are yet to feature after being given extended breaks following their involvement with their respective countries at Euro 2024 and Copa America.

United have until September 2 to complete any more deals for new signings. MEN Sport has taken a look at some of the latest pieces of speculation that have been doing the rounds online and across social media over the last 24 hours.

United are being credited with an interest in signing Brentford striker Ivan Toney. The Athletic have reported that United could still add to their striker options despite the arrival of Zirkzee from Bologna.

It has been reported that Toney is a target for United as they look to add further striker depth to their squad. United now have Rasmus Hojlund and Zirkzee as centre-forward options and the arrival of Toney would add increased competition for a starting spot in the team.

Elsewhere, United are continuing to be linked with a move for Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Manuel Ugarte. According to Give Me Sport, United are considering a change of strategy when it comes to signing Ugarte.

It has been claimed that United are now weighing up whether or not to try and sign Ugarte on loan rather than on a permanent deal. United have already signed Zirkzee and are looking to add further new signings to their squad this summer. The signing of Ugarte on loan would provide more financial room for the Reds to work with when it comes to adding new players to the squad.

headline: Man United could get £15m transfer boost from West Ham despite Jean-Clair Todibo agreement
body: United had been linked with a move for Todibo but West Ham could them a favour despite agreeing a deal for the Frenchman
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
West Ham United could be about to hand Manchester United a major transfer boost, despite the Hammers reaching an agreement to sign former target Jean-Clair Todibo.

Todibo had been linked with a move to Old Trafford this summer but UEFA's multi-ownership rules blocked them making a move for the Nice defender, as the French club are also owned by INEOS. Interest in the France international is high, though, and despite it looking like he was going to join Juventus, West Ham have agreed a deal with Nice to sign the 24-year-old.

The Hammers have struck an initial loan deal with an option to sign Todibo for £27million next summer and it is now up to the player to decide whether he wants to move to East London. West Ham are looking to reshape their defence under new manager Julen Lopetegui and have already signed Max Kilman from Wolverhampton Wanderers for £40million.

And as part of that reshuffle, The Telegraph report they are keen to sign Manchester United right-back Aaron Wan-Bissaka this summer. The 26-year-old is out of contract next summer and this transfer window represents the last chance United have to recoup a significant fee for a player they paid £40million to sign from Crystal Palace five years ago.

Reports suggest West Ham want to strike a £15million deal for Wan-Bissaka, and while that would represent a significant loss on the fee they paid to sign him, any player sales will go towards United's own rebuild this summer. Erik ten Hag's side have already secured the £36million signing of Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna, while they are expected to seal a £58.7million deal for Lille defender Leny Yoro.

As such, they will need to trade players in order to bring in some more signings this summer, with the likes of Matthijs De Ligt, Jarrad Branthwaite and Manuel Ugarte linked with moves to Old Trafford.

Any money they receive for the likes of Wan-Bissaka, Mason Greenwood, Victor Lindelof and possibly even Scott McTominay would fund moves for Ten Hag to give his side a major refresh in the summer transfer window.

headline: Thierry Henry verdict on Leny Yoro speaks volumes before Manchester United transfer
body: Latest Manchester United transfer news and gossip as United close in on the signing of Lille centre-back Leny Yoro who has received praise from Thierry Henry
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Thierry Henry has already given a glowing verdict on Leny Yoro as Manchester United edge closer to signing the defender.

United have already agreed a deal to sign Yoro this summer from French club Lille. A deal worth €70million (£58.7million) has been agreed between United and Lille and now the player is expected to become the second new signing of the summer at Old Trafford.

It was confirmed last Sunday that Joshua Zirkzee had become the first signing of the summer for United. Now the Reds are moving closer to adding Yoro to Erik ten Hag's squad, with the centre-back also expected to travel with his new United teammates to the United States for their upcoming pre-season schedule.

Henry has experience working alongside Yoro with his role as France Under-21 head coach. The Arsenal legend handed Yoro his debut for the Under-21s in September last year when the defender was 17 years old.

It was back in March that Henry explained why he had been so impressed by Yoro in the early stages of his career. The comments from the Arsenal legend will offer encouragement of what United will hope to enjoy from Yoro in the years to come once he completes a move to Old Trafford - and explain why the club have moved for him.
“We often talk about Leny,” Henry told Le Petit Lillois back in March. “He is having an exemplary start to his career. To establish himself in Lille as he is doing…
“He always has some young reactions, and that is completely normal. It comes slowly, you make mistakes and sometimes you get embarrassed.
“(But) he goes on to play one match after another, he starts quite often and quite often is good. It’s really good for him. He is professional, he’s a good guy, well-educated.
“I like him. He performs well. Afterwards, there are always things to refine, but that’s completely normal. Frankly, it’s really a more than positive progression.”

headline: Everton baffled by Leny Yoro fee amid Manchester United bids for Jarrad Branthwaite
body: Leny Yoro is joining Man United for a fee rising to €70m after the club had lower offers rejected for Jarrad Branthwaite.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United's agreement to sign Leny Yoro has only emboldened Everton's stance on Jarrad Branthwaite.
Everton rejected two offers of £43million and £50m from United for Branthwaite before the club agreed a fee rising to €70m (£62m) with Lille for Yoro.
Branthwaite, 21, is valued at between £70m and £80m by Everton while the 18-year-old Yoro is joining United for an initial £52m.

It is understood figures at Everton are surprised United have agreed a steep fee for a defender three years younger than Branthwaite who is out of contract next year, has no international experience and plays in Ligue 1.
United sources cited a budget of "tens of millions" behind their opening offer of £35m plus £8m in add-ons for Branthwaite last month.

External sources claim United have "plenty" to spend as two of their highest earners in Raphael Varane and Anthony Martial were released and the club have banked fees for Alvaro Fernandez, Donny van de Beek and Willy Kambwala, with Mason Greenwood expected to depart for nearly £30m.

Yoro was omitted from the France Under-23 squad for the Olympics in Paris later this month while Branthwaite was cut from Gareth Southgate's provisional England squad for the European Championship. Branthwaite attained his first cap against Bosnia and Herzegovina last month.

Branthwaite signed a new contract with Everton until 2027 last year and the Goodison Park club have flagged fees paid by United, Chelsea and Manchester City for Harry Maguire (£80m), Wesley Fofana (£75m) and Josko Gvardiol (£77.6m) in the past five years to justify their valuation of Branthwaite. Everton are also on the brink of selling Amadou Onana to Aston Villa for £50m.
United have form for irking Everton in the transfer market, having submitted a joint £28m offer for Leighton Baines and Marouane Fellaini in 2013.
Everton dismissed the offer as "derisory and insulting". United eventually signed only Fellaini on deadline day for £27.5m when he had a release clause for £23.5m earlier that summer.

headline: Mason Greenwood takes final Man United transfer action before Marseille deal
body: Mason Greenwood is close to sealing a move away from Manchester United
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Mason Greenwood is close to sealing a move away from Manchester United and has travelled to France to complete the formalities of a transfer to Marseille.

The 22-year-old forward has not played for United since January 2022 following his arrest for attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviour and assault occasioning actual bodily harm. After the charges were dropped against Greenwood, he spent last season on loan at La Liga side Getafe.

Now, the one-cap England international, who has been on United's books since the age of seven, is close to sealing a permanent move away from Old Trafford after Marseille agreed a deal with United on Wednesday, the Manchester Evening News understands.

Greenwood is expected to undergo a medical in France and finalise the formalities of the transfer. It is a deal that is expected to see the Reds pocket an initial £23.3m, with that potentially rising to £26.7m. If Greenwood's move to Stade Velodrome is complete, it will be the highest transfer fee United have received for an academy graduate since Sir Alex Ferguson retired in 2013.
The forward had less than 12 months remaining on his current deal but the United had the option to extend by a further 12 months.

headline: Man United 'set deadline' for Leny Yoro arrival amid Liverpool transfer hijack prospects
body: Manchester United seem keen to get his deal signed and sealed to see another summer transfer objective ticked off.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United have been active in the transfer market over recent weeks, and look set to welcome in their second signing of the window.

Leny Yoro is poised to join on a deal that could rise to around £60m, while Joshua Zirkzee has already been secured after a £36m agreement with Bologna. United have batted off interest from Real Madrid and Liverpool to land Yoro, who will pen a five-year deal at Old Trafford.

The teenager has undergone his medical having flown into Manchester on Wednesday with an announcement anticipated soon. United staff are keen on the deal to be officially wrapped up sooner rather than later and are said to have outlined a timeline in which they wish to see the transfer ratified.
A report from the Daily Mail claims United are keen to see Yoro registered as a United player by Friday. While a medical has been completed, personal terms are yet to be finalised in full.

United want to leave no space for a potential U-turn, with several previous reports claiming Yoro had preferred a move to Real Madrid, who seemingly did not echo the same enthusiasm. Liverpool and Paris Saint-Germain had mulled over an approach for Yoro too.
Getting a deal over the line would add more clarity when it comes to Premier League spending limits. United are set to dish out an initial £42m for Yoro with the rest being topped up by add-ons.

MEN Sport says:United’s eagerness is understandable but it is unlikely clubs will make a late dive for Yoro at this stage, unless the player has second thoughts. The fact he’s taken the effort to fly to Manchester for a medical suggests he hasn’t any.

Perhaps the desire for a quick arrival is so he is ready in time for United’s pre-season tour of the USA, which begins a week on Sunday with the flight over there scheduled for a few days beforehand. Friday’s 'deadline' would allow Yoro to be unveiled to United fans at Murrayfield during their friendly with Scotland on Saturday.

Liverpool will not make a last-ditch move for Yoro, says the Liverpool Echo. Arne Slot is not seeing centre-back reinforcement as a priority this summer, although his club did attain interest in the exiting Lille defender.

It had been expected that the Reds would make a move for Yoro should a move to Real break down, with club chiefs admirers of his play and excited over his potential. However, Liverpool are not willing to match United’s lofty offer.
Yoro is not guaranteed game time at Anfield with Jarell Quansah, Ibrahima Konate and Joe Gomez all options to partner captain Virgil van Dijk.

MEN Sport says:It is undoubtedly a statement of intent that United have managed to beat Liverpool to Yoro, with both clubs entering new eras. At the same time, the price tag is also a risk, albeit a calculated one given the hype around the teenager.
Time will tell whether it is a good buy, but the United board seem to have been keen on the move. The new hierarchy’s transfer reputation will be impacted by how well he progresses.

headline: What Leny Yoro transfer means for Man United FFP situation as £42m truth explained
body: Manchester United's FFP situation has been explained after Leny Yoro transfer
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

Manchester United have the 'flexibility' with their current profit and sustainability rules (PSR) situation to move for Lille defender Leny Yoro but they will need to sell off talent if they are to make future additions, such as Jarrad Branthwaite.
That is the view of Reach Football's Business of Football expert Dave Powell, who has outlined United's current financial situation after a busy start to their summer transfer window.
United have sold three players already, with Donny van de Beek (Girona), Willy Kambwala (Villarreal) and Alvaro Fernandez (Benfica) moved on.

In terms of incomings, they have already announced the £36million signing of Dutch international forward Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna and they are set to seal the arrival of teenage defender Leny Yoro from Lille imminently.
The 18-year-old will join for an initial £42m, with the rest of the fee made up of add-ons as United look to overhaul their defensive options.

They have also agreed personal terms with Bayern Munich's Matthijs De Ligt and have had two bids rejected for Everton defender Jarrad Branthwaite. However, they may need to sell the likes of Mason Greenwood and Victor Lindelof to help fund those deals.

“Now into a new financial year, Manchester United have the ability to be more flexible with additions, although the sales of the likes of Donny van de Beek, Willy Kambwala, and Alvaro Fernandez should be instructive as to United’s approach to the summer window, which will require money to be recouped before adding yet more transfer debt, something Sir Jim Ratcliffe wants to reduce," Powell said.

“The reported fee for Leny Yoro is €62m (£52m), with €50m (£42m) of that guaranteed and the rest made up of add-ons. For amortisation purposes, only the £42m guaranteed sum would be accounted for annually, which would be £8.4m per year on the assumption that he signs a five-year deal.
"The add-ons would appear on the balance sheet as extraordinary costs as and when they are activated, be it through performance or making a certain number of appearances.
“With the sales of Kambwala and Fernandez both being sales of United graduates, they allow for the club to book pure profit to the tune of some £11.4m combined.

"As for Van de Beek, the Dutchman had one year left on his United deal, and a remaining book value of £7m, although loan fees recouped from his time elsewhere means that has largely been accounted for. United have reportedly received a fee of £423,000, but it is a deal that has add-ons that could rise to as high as £5m, plus it removes some wage pressures on the payroll.

“United have the flexibility to move for Yoro, and cashflow isn’t an issue in terms of a payment plan, but in order for future additions, such as Jarrad Branthwaite, they will likely have to go to the well of selling off talent, with Mason Greenwood, Victor Lindelof, and Harry Maguire all potentially on the block, although a profit on Maguire may be challenging.”

headline: Erik ten Hag was proved right in Manchester United friendly vs Rosenborg
body: Man United were deservedly beaten by Rosenborg in a Norwegian friendly that Erik ten Hag will have learnt little from.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United have played in Norway in five of their last six pre-season schedules and the organisers may want to reconsider that jaunt for next summer's schedule.

Five members of the 25-man United squad were senior players and it showed in a sterile friendly that sounded about as atmospheric as a Sunday league game. United ambassador Ronny Johnsen went off-message during MUTV's coverage when he commented on how quiet the atmosphere was. Such is the enthusiasm of United's Nordic following, it was a 21,000 sell-out at the Lerkendal Stadium.

The referee's refusal to put everyone out of their misery and add three minutes of stoppage time did at least yield a goal in the 93rd-minute winner from Rosenborg substitute Noah Emmanuel Jean Holm. That was the least the dominant hosts merited against a hotchpotch United. "The performance was below standards," Erik ten Hag admitted.

The Norwegian contingent of United's support did not expect European Championship or Copa America participants but would have anticipated the presence of Andre Onana, Harry Maguire, Victor Lindelof, Antony and Amad.

That quintet was back at Carrington. Steve McClaren, not in Norway, is on crutches after a foot operation, so the training back at base will have been minimal. United could at least have fielded a five-a-side team in the local power league.
Back in Norway, Ten Hag learnt little. He did not say that, of course. Jose Mourinho was not shy in dismissing friendly matches with shadow squads and this was a particularly pointless excursion.
Not for everyone, though. Radek Vitek was exceptional in goal, Ethan Wheatley was one of the few bright starters and Toby Collyer captained United on his maiden senior appearance.
Nine of the players who emerged for the second half had never played under Ten Hag. They will always be able to say they represented the United first team and cherish their match shirts.

Couching this as a first team friendly was disingenuous. It was about as senior as the United academy's exhibition match with Wrexham in San Diego last year. That turned out to be their most eventful tour fixture, with Paul Mullin maimed by United's goalkeeping competition winner Nathan Bishop.

Vitek replaced Bishop at the pause that evening and his performance in Norway would suggest he has a higher ceiling. The 20-year-old pulled off at least five saves and his glove onto the crossbar from Emil Frederikson was world-class. The United goal led a charmed life and Rosenborg hit the woodwork four times.

United have stockpiled goalkeepers from Eastern Europe in recent years but they made a tidy profit on the impressive Matej Kovar when he joined Bayer Leverkusen for €9million next year. His compatriot Vitek, on loan at League Two Accrington Stanley earlier this year, will not be playing at that low a level next season.

At the other end, Wheatley applied himself with a purpose that suggests he does not want to be remembered as United's 250th academy graduate. The 18-year-old's portrait now graces the Jimmy Murphy Young Player of the Year plaque at Carrington and last year it was Kobbie Mainoo's face.

“In my team talk, I said yesterday, Copa America final: involving Alejandro Garnacho," Ten Hag told MUTV before kick-off. "Euros final: Kobbie Mainoo. Last season, same game (against Leeds United in Oslo): Kobbie Mainoo was part of that match."
There was not a performance comparable with Mainoo's accomplished half against Leeds but Wheatley was responsible for United's only attempt on target in a humdrum first half.

Mason Mount endeavoured to raise the tempo and played Wheatley in. Mount, starting in midfield with Casemiro, will struggle to stay there when Mainoo returns from his overdue holiday and Ten Hag may have to tinker with his role over the next few weeks against Rangers, Arsenal, Real Betis and Liverpool.

Ten Hag opined to a confidant towards the end of last season the rookies he was forced to name on the bench were not ready. That was apparent against the 11th-placed Norwegian side (out of 16), though Rosenborg are 14 games into the Tippeligaen season.

Collyer, Habeeb Ogunneye, Rhys Bennett, Harry Amass and Joe Hugill were all unused substitutes in first team games last season. Bennett's positioning was awry for the only goal yet he lacked support from those in front of him.
A little like Vitek.

headline: Erik ten Hag's new catchphrase shows what Manchester United must change this season
body: Man Utd will face more demands than ever before this season and that is a concern after a campaign wrecked by a dreadful fitness record.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

Listening to Erik ten Hag speak in Norway you were left with the impression that two things in particular will need to change for this season go better than the last one. Manchester United's fitness record must improve and Ineos' new football structure needs to deliver greater depth to the squad.

Ten Hag didn't put a number on the quantity of signings required to be competitive again, instead pointing to the fact with most of his first-team stars available United ended last season by 'beating the best team in the world'. You can't argue with that.

They didn't show that level consistently enough, however, which is why they finished eighth in the Premier League. Ten Hag constantly pointed to a disastrous injury record to mitigate that underperformance.

He is expecting this summer to beef up his squad, although it remains possible that the numbers will shrink with several players likely to be sold. It will be about shoring up the quality just behind the starting XI, which is what the £35.7m deal for Joshua Zirkzee does, while spending £52m on an 18-year-old Leny Yoro is another example of adding real quality to the squad.

After that, it will be about getting players fit and keeping them there. Ten Hag has made no secret of the running requirements to play his style of football and in Trondheim, there was a hint of unhappiness about the physical capacity of some of his players in the first week of pre-season.

The demands are only going to rise this season. United will play eight Europa League group games rather than six, with the league structure now finishing in January. The players themselves might be relieved they haven't qualified for FIFA's dreadful Club World Cup next summer, a month-long tournament that finally turns the sport into a year-round jamboree where pockets are lined but players are exploited.

For now, United's squad can at least comfort themselves with the idea of a break at the end of the season, but Ten Hag didn't exactly play down the most important aspect of the season ahead. "You need squad depth," he said. "Then it's about survival of the fittest."

That sounds like a neat catchphrase for the start of the game's most demanding season yet. It will also set alarm bells ringing at Carrington given last season resembled more an episode of Casualty than Bear Grylls.

End-of-season research by the Premier Injuries website revealed United suffered the most in 2023/24, with 45 separate cases affecting 21 players, with a total of 1,620 days lost to those on the sidelines. That doesn't include Tyrell Malacia, who was injured before the season started and never returned.

Those injuries robbed Ten Hag of continuity, especially in defence, and the medical issues have to be rectified for this season. Many of those problems were muscle injuries picked up in training at Carrington.

This season won't just be about a repeat of avoiding those setbacks, however. It's not solely about not getting injuries, but about being fit enough to outrun the opposition twice a week, week after week. That is partly what Ten Hag is getting at when he says this season will be the "survival of the fittest."

We know how important running stats are to Ten Hag. He made that perfectly clear when his team were trampled all over by Brentford in just his second game in charge. There were some grumbles in pre-season a year ago about the demanding nature of some of the double sessions.

This summer United are cutting down on travelling and will spend a significant chunk of their US tour in Los Angeles. It will make for a better work environment and was a key demand for Ten Hag when planning the trip.

On those training pitches, he will hope to lay the foundations for a season when the ability of teams to keep going will be tested more than ever before. It will be survival of the fittest and Ten Hag will be desperate to make sure his players are ready for the challenge.

headline: What Leny Yoro transfer means for Manchester United and Matthijs de Ligt ahead of £137m decision
body: The latest Manchester United transfer news as the club are closing in on a move for 18-year-old defender Leny Yoro amid talks over a transfer for Matthijs de Ligt.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United appear to be closing in on their second signing of the summer transfer window, with defender Leny Yoro agreeing to join.

United had a bid accepted by Lille for the 18-year-old last week, but the teenager was said to have his heart set on a move to Real Madrid. It now seems that he has changed his mind and has decided to push on with a move to Old Trafford.
A deal for Yoro could rise to as much as €70 million (£58.7m) with add-ons. If a deal goes through then he is expected to be available for the club’s pre-season tour in America next week.

Yoro’s arrival could however have a big impact on another transfer the club has been working on. United have been in talks over a move for Bayern Munich defender Matthijs de Ligt for the last few weeks and have reached a verbal agreement with the Dutchman over personal terms.

However, reports this week suggested that the transfer had been delayed due to the move for Yoro. De Ligt is valued at £42 million by Bayern, and it is said that United didn’t have an expectation of signing both the 24-year-old and Yoro this summer, suggesting that interest in the Ajax man could now be dropped.

It leaves United with a decision to make. If they push ahead with a move for De Ligt it would take their spending up to £137.2 million on three transfers. United confirmed the £36.5 million capture of Bologna striker Joshua Zirkzee over the weekend.

Erik ten Hag has been keen to add to his defensive options this summer, with the departure of Raphael Varane. There has also been uncertainty over the future of Harry Maguire and Victor Lindelof who are both out of contract next year, the club will need replacements if one, or even both move on this summer.

One thing that could point towards the club continuing their pursuit of De Ligt was their stance on Jarrad Branthwaite. It was reported that United were keen to do deals for both the Everton man and De Ligt this summer, when news of interest in the Ajax centre-back emerged.

Branthwaite will have cost United more in terms of transfer fee than Yoro has. If the club have therefore moved on from the Everton defender, then the plan to sign De Ligt could potentially remain in place.
United have unveiled their new adidas home kit with new front-of-shirt sponsors for the 2024/25 season - and you can get your hands on it right now.

headline: Manchester United have four players to challenge for Premier League after transfer breakthrough
body: Man Utd have made a breakthrough in talks to sign Leny Yoro and the player is on his way to Manchester for a medical.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Sir Jim Ratcliffe was charmed by Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho and Rasmus Hojlund posing together on the Old Trafford advertising hoardings after a goal last season.
Those players are the future of Manchester United and Leny Yoro can be added to that bracket when he completes his transfer from Lille in a deal that could rise to €70million.

That fee equates to £58.7m which represents value for a player who is regarded as one of the brightest prospects in European football. Real Madrid were interested in Yoro but United have made a breakthrough and his signing will be a statement of intent.

Yoro is just 18 years old and his potential is vast. United could build their defence around the Frenchman for the next decade and he will complete a young core of the team, with Mainoo in midfield, Hojlund leading the attack and Garnacho on the left or right wing.
Yoro is the type of signing Sir Alex Ferguson would target and he possesses similar raw attributes to Rio Ferdinand when the United great was on the cusp of signing from Leeds.
It made sense for Lille to sell Yoro considering he'd entered the final year of his contract, but United have done well to steal a march on their rivals to make a breakthrough to sign him.

Yoro is on his way to Manchester for a medical and he will become the club's second signing of the summer window after the arrival of Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna for £36.5m. United have made a strong start to the transfer window and there is still plenty more work to do.
However, the signing of Yoro should be regarded as a coup and supporters have already shared their delight at the club landing one of the hottest prospects in football.

Yoro made his senior debut for Lille aged 16 and it didn't take long for him to become a key first-team player. He made 44 appearances in all competitions last season - not starting in just one of those games - and demonstrated his quality against Aston Villa in the Conference League.
Aston Villa progressed to the semi-finals of the Conference League with a victory over Lille on penalties, but Yoro announced himself to a wider British audience over those two legs.
Although Yoro still has scope to physically mature, which is par for the course at his age, he oozed quality and composure against Villa and that bodes well for this season.
The Premier League poses different challenges to Ligue 1, but Yoro is equipped with the attributes to succeed in England and will become an even better player with the benefit of time.

United fans want to challenge for the Premier League title as soon as possible but they aren't daft. The club hasn't come close to winning the league since 2013 - United were 19 points behind Manchester City in 2017/18 - and a title challenge is at least a few years away, realistically.
Ratcliffe has shared that sentiment in his interviews since acquiring a minority stake and the early signs of his co-ownership show United are taking a longer-term view for success.
United are hopeful Yoro will develop into one of the world's best defenders and he's the final piece of a talented, youthful core that could play together for many years.

Mainoo confirmed himself as an exceptional prospect last season and was superb at Euro 2024 for England. Hojlund enjoyed a solid first season, scoring 16 goals, and Garnacho has been likened to a young Cristiano Ronaldo, who was full of confidence yet raw at United.
When you add Yoro to that list of players, United have four talented youngsters who will eventually form the core of the team, which is a genuinely exciting prospect to savour.
It might take five years to challenge for the Premier League, but Ratcliffe is building for long-term success and United undoubtedly have an exciting crop of youngsters.

headline: Manchester United discover Leny Yoro availability as key pre-season decision already made
body: Leny Yoro will be granted time to bed into Man United ahead of the new season thanks to Lille's transfer-fuelled decision earlier this summer.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Leny Yoro is set to become Manchester United’s second signing of the summer, taking the club’s top-end spend to £95m.

It is thought Sir Jim Ratcliffe is only permitting an overall net expenditure of around £50m, with just over £10m received for the sales of Donny van de Beek and Willy Kambwala. United have meanwhile agreed a £26.7m fee from Marseille for Mason Greenwood.

A sum of £36m was paid out to Bologna for the acquisition of Joshua Zirkzee, who is currently on a short break after his inclusion in the Netherlands squad for Euro 2024. He missed Monday’s friendly in Norway against Rosenborg and might also be exempt from Saturday’s fixture with Rangers at Murrayfield.

The game also probably comes too soon for Yoro, who joins on a deal worth £52m rising up to just under £59m. United begin their pre-season tour of the US on July 28 when they face Arsenal in California.
Zirkzee will have joined up with the squad by then as will Yoro thanks to a decision made early this summer.

The defender was ultimately not selected to take part in France’s campaign at this summer’s Olympics, with the men’s football event running from July 24. The gold medal match takes place on August 9, just eight days before the start of the Premier League season.

Clubs are not obliged to release their players for the tournament given it is not a Fifa-sanctioned event, and so Lille prevented Yoro from being called up. This meant the club could seal a fee for his transfer more easily, with inclusion in the Olympics almost certain to have stagnated negotiations.
The further positive consequence for United sees Yoro available for pre-season, having had the opportunity to secure the transfer of the 18-year-old in good time.

It affords Erik ten Hag more breathing space to sort out his team blueprint ahead of the new season, with Yoro set to be available for at least three pre-season friendlies ahead of the Community Shield clash against Manchester City on August 10, once his move is finalised.

headline: 'That's what we need' - Ex-Man Utd star tells Sir Jim Ratcliffe to sign England duo
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has already made his first signing at Manchester United, but Paul Ince believes the squad needs a new striker with Premier League experience if they're to improve
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe has been advised to target English stars Ivan Toney and Ollie Watkins this summer.

Ratcliffe recently began his first summer as a United investor by signing Bologna forward Joshua Zirkzee for £36.5million, while Lille's teenage centre-half Leny Yoro is on his way to Old Trafford too for around £50m. But the British billionaire has a significant amount of work on his hands if he hopes to improve the club's fortunes in the coming campaign.

A surprising 1-0 pre-season defeat to Norwegian team Rosenborg highlighted the challenges that lie ahead, and it's clear United's transfer dealings are far from over. Former Old Trafford star Paul Ince has urged his old club to prioritise securing an experienced Premier League striker - specifically Toney and Watkins - to alleviate the scoring pressure on young Rasmus Hojlund.

Aston Villa ace Watkins and Brentford frontman Toney made waves with their performances for England at Euro 2024. Toney confidently converted his penalty in the shootout win against Switzerland, while Watkins scored a memorable goal against the Netherlands to propel England into the final.

Both players have attracted considerable attention this summer, with Toney of particular interest to clubs as his contract expires in 2025. The Bees will be reluctant to let their top scorer leave for free next year, however, making a sale during this transfer window likely.

Ince, 56, firmly believes United desperately need a major revamp, with a particular focus on recruiting a striker who can consistently find the back of the net at the highest level. In an interview with Ladbrokes 1-2-Free (via The Mirror), he said: "They've got to strengthen a lot this summer.

"When you look at a team before pre-season starts, and you start identifying where you might want to strengthen, you don't want to make wholesale changes. You know, you want to keep the core of the team. But when you look at Manchester United, they need at least seven players, arguably in the starting XI."

United have to be careful about spending outside their means despite winning the FA Cup to qualify for next season's Europa League. And Ince went on to identify other specific areas in which reinforcements are required, with striker top of the wish-list.

He continued: "Raphael Varane is gone now, Lisandro Martinez has been injured pretty much all season, so there's an issue there; can he compete for 40 or more games per season? We've got Aaron Wan-Bissaka, who we're trying to sell. Luke Shaw has spent a lot of time out.

"Casemiro is going to move on, and we still haven't found that holding number six. Antony hasn't been performing, so do you get someone in to replace him? Marcus Rashford hasn't been at his best, and Rasmus Hojlund is still a young striker. That's so many areas of the pitch you would say need improving.

"I think that's what we need to get; a top, top striker, like an Ollie Watkins, like an Ivan Toney. Someone like that, who knows the league, to play up front and let Hojlund take his time and settle in. Listen, I'm sure the new people behind the scenes know what they're doing."

A proven striker in England's top-flight is sure to command a hefty fee. Brentford have reportedly put a £60m price tag on Toney despite his contract expiring next summer, and Villa would demand more for Watkins.

The player's current market value is understood to be around £85m, but that could increase as Villa look to offload other assets to balance their books. Douglas Luiz's £42m sale to Juventus has already helped ease their woes in that sector, but other departures may be on the cards.
Winger Moussa Diaby is believed to be attracting interest from Saudi Arabian clubs, while back-up forward Jhon Duran is on West Ham's radar.
With several potential departures at United, the funds raised could pave the way for them to make a move for either of the England stars.

headline: Leny Yoro's Lille teammate breaks ranks with huge Manchester United transfer endorsement
body: Man United are closing in on the signing of Lille defender Leny Yoro with the Frenchman due to arrive in Manchester shortly to finalise personal terms on a £58.7million move
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Imminent Manchester United signing Leny Yoro has received high praise from his Lille teammate Angel Gomes.

United have agreed a £58.7million deal with the French club for the 18-year-old, who is set to fly to Manchester to finalise personal terms. Yoro had been on Real Madrid's radar, but the Spanish giants were unwilling to meet Lille's asking price.

United academy graduate Gomes, who left Old Trafford in June 2020 after just 10 senior appearances, has been impressed by Yoro's maturity and ability to fit into the first-team environment at Lille despite his young age. Previously speaking to Eurosport, he said: "As soon as he arrived in the group, I understood that he was going to reach the summits.

"When I discovered the pros at the age of 16 at Manchester United, I understood that it was different. He already had the right temperament. That's not normal for a 16- or 17-year-old player arriving. It's like he's already an experienced player and it showed in the way he trained, the way he behaved. His progress was obvious."
While investing in young talent can be risky, United have reaped the rewards of trusting their youth players, with Kobbie Mainoo and Alejandro Garnacho making significant strides.

United are keen to strengthen their defence following a challenging season. Erik ten Hag has identified Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Jarrad Branthwaite as potential targets, with the aim of securing at least two of these players. However, the acquisition of a second player may hinge on the future of Victor Lindelof and Harry Maguire.

Lille's president, Olivier Letang, has confirmed that Yoro will be available for transfer this summer. Initially, Yoro favoured a move to Real Madrid, but United's persuasive approach has swayed him towards an immediate transfer - a preference shared by his current club.
United's management sees Yoro as a promising talent who could become a key figure in their defence over the next decade.
